content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> is a real number. The Taylor series for a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="the sum, from k equals 1, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator 2 to the k power, and denominator 3 k, end fraction, times x to the k power"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find <math alttext="the fifth derivative of f, of 0"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> is a real number. The Taylor series for a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="the sum, from k equals 1, to infinity, of the fraction with numerator 2 to the k power, and denominator 3 k, end fraction, times x to the k power"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munderover><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find <math alttext="the fifth derivative of f, of 0"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(b) Use the ratio test to find the interval of convergence of the Taylor series for <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Use the second-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to approximate <math alttext="f of one fourth"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Given that <math alttext="the absolute value of, f triple prime of x, end absolute value, is less than or equal to the fraction 128 over 3"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>128</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="negative one fourth less than or equal to x, less than or equal to one fourth"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, use the Lagrange error bound to show that the approximation from part (c) differs from <math alttext="f of one fourth"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> by at most <math alttext="one ninth"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Identify a re-expression of mathematical information presented in a given representation
